answers.answer: There are many happy stories out there. The drains staying in for a month is not a complication, but should be an expectation. Many of my patients do go back to work within 4 weeks of surgery, but usually 1/2 day at first. The capsular scarring can occur, but usually less than 5% of the time. Infections can occur in anyone any time they have surgery. There are many things to consider, but the good things generally far outweigh the bad, and you sound healthy, and would have lower risk factors. Good luck.arch s miller ms md facs

question: I am 57 and had (L) breast removed at 40; second one on (R) side end of July, 2009.  By the by, no genetic mutation.  Just unlucky I guess!  Anyway - I have the opportunity to get recon on both sides but am really afraid.  I have read only horror stories about capsular contracture, MRSA in wound, drains on for over a month, removal of expanders - I mean, how does a person go to work amidst all this happening?  I would like to know - are there some recons that go seamlessly - that have the requisite pain, no infectoin, proper expansion and exchange and a good result.  I have recon planned on both - but I might just chicken out for fear of the limitless things that could go wrong and just stick with 2 prosthesis.  Are there good stories out there.  I am otherwise healthy, thin, no diabetes, do no smoke and have not had previous radiation so I am told, a good candidate on paper.  Thank you.
title: Breast recon on new BC breast removal and prior 17 years back - how will recon work?
